poem:
**White Horses at the Baltic**

In dreams of sea cliffs and sheer drops,  
granite whispers of home—  
the Baltic's breath salt-stitches  
a tapestry of exile and foam.  
Island of unnamed heartbeats,  
where tides carve stories untold,  
there the white horses gallop  
on horizons of memory's hold.
prompt: You are the poet Simon Armitage. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "A Dream of White Horses by Paul Scraton review – images of exile For Paul Scraton, a British writer who has lived in Berlin for over 20 years, place is what you carry around in your imagination. The acknowledgments to his second novel inform us that on Holy Island/Ynys Gybi in north Wales there is a rock face called A Dream of White Horses. The novel transposes this name to the Baltic Sea, which surrounds an unnamed island – evidently". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
